author: Harriet O'Brien
title: The 5 best family days out from Bristol
text: Follow the links below to see the rest of our guide • The best family days out from Manchester • The best family days out from Birmingham • The best family days out from Newcastle • The best family days out from London Wild Place Project Make dinner for wolves, feed rare okapi or enjoy the adrenalin rush of a high-wire course. Part wildlife, part adventure playground, this outlet of Bristol Zoo, on the western edge of the city, has continued to expand since it opened in 2013. There is a huge amount to do for children ages five and up, from meeting mongooses and lemurs to following barefoot trails. Heart-pumping action is offered in the Leap of Faith adventure park, with seven exhilarating challenges. 0117 980 7175; wildplace.org.uk; adult £6.34, child £5.68 (10 per cent discount if you order tickets online); Leap of Faith from £8 per person. Linger with lemurs at Wild Place Project, an outlet of Bristol Zoo The Strawberry Line Cycle a section of the Cheddar Valley railway, which closed in 1965 and is now a 10-mile bike route passing through woodland and around orchards. It’s mostly off-road and flat, so ideal for young families (there are short road sections at Congresbury, Sandford and Axbridge). Stop at Sandford Station Heritage Centre or postcard-pretty Axbridge. Yatton is half an hour’s drive south of Bristol, or take the train. Webbs of Warmley on Bath Road offers good bicycle rentals. 0117 932 5763; thestrawberryline.org.uk ; webbsofwarmley.com ; £15 a day. • The 20 best hidden beaches in the UK • How to survive a family trip to the zoo • Flying with children: 10 secrets to stress-free travel Burnham, Berrow and Brean Down beaches A 45-minute drive south of Bristol, this is the best stretch of beach within easy reach of the city, and it presents a happy variety of British seaside life. Burnham’s main beach offers everything from donkey rides to boating and jet skis; quieter Berrow has sand dunes, an ancient shipwreck that is exposed at low tide, and the occasional naturist. The National Trust’s Brean Down beach offers great walks. Note: at low tide, Bristol Channel waters can be dangerous. thebeachguide.co.uk , burnham-on-sea.com ; free. Berrow beach's shipwreck Photo: Alamy Cotswold Country Park and beach Just under an hour’s drive north east of Bristol, this area produced gravel until the Seventies, when the pits were filled with water and about 150 lakes were created. These now serve as either wildlife habitats or lively centres for watersports. An inviting range of activities (for an extra charge) is on offer for all ages, with an inland beach, swimming, kayaking, canoeing, aqua zorbing (walking on water in a huge plastic ball) and more. 01285 868096; cotswoldcountrypark.co.uk ; adult £5, child £2. • 50 great days out in the UK • Holiday complaints: what to do when things go wrong • How to survive a long car journey with children Cheddar Gorge X-treme With vertiginous cliffs, weathered crags and deep caverns, the wonderworld of Cheddar Gorge is about 45 minutes south of Bristol. Take a picnic and harness yourself up with X-treme for a breathtaking challenge. This is gutsy stuff for over-11s: guides will take you climbing up a 50ft rock face, or, with headlamps and helmets, 40ft underground into the astounding network of caves. Querulous parents need not accompany their children; intrepid adults are welcome. 01934 742343; cheddargorge.co.uk ; adult £22, child £20. Follow @telegraphtravel
